Virus particles (digitally colored purple) are 40 [[Nanometre|nm]] in diameter, with an outer envelope and a dense inner core.ref name="zikamicrograph"{{cite web | date=18 March 2005 | accessdate=4 March 2016 | first1=Cynthia | last1=Goldsmith | url= http://phil.cdc.gov/phil/details.asp?pid=20487 | title=Zika Virus | website=[[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]]}}</ref> image2 = Zika-chain-colored.png image2_caption = Zika virus [[viral envelope|envelope]] model, colored by chains, [[Protein Data Bank|PDB]] entry PDBe5ire.ref name="SirohiChen2016"{{cite journal | date=31 March 2016 | display-authors=3 | first1=D. | journal=Science | volume=352 | issue=6284 | pages=467\u201370 | last1=Sirohi | url= http://science.sciencemag.org/content/early/2016/04/01/science.aaf5316 | title=The 3.8 \u00c5 resolution cryo-EM structure of Zika virus | last2=Chen | first2=Z. | last3=Sun | first3=L. | last4=Klose | first4=T. | last5=Pierson | first5=T. virus''<!-- Virology -->'''Zika virus''' ('''ZIKV''') is a member of the [[virus]] [[family (biology)|family]] ''[[Flaviviridae]]'' and the [[genus]] ''[[Flavivirus]]''.ref name="MaloneHoman2016"{{cite journal | date=2 March 2016 | display-authors=3 | first1=Robert W. | first10=Ivan | first11=Julie | first12=Daniel | first13=James | last1=Malone | last10=Ruzic | last11=Smith-Gagen | last12=Janies | last13=Wilson | url= http://journals.plos.org/plosntds/article?id=10.1371/journal.pntd.0004530 | title=Zika Virus: Medical Countermeasure Development Challenges | last2=Homan | first2=Jane | last3=Callahan | first3=Michael V. | last4=Glasspool-Malone | first4=Jill | last5=Damodaran | first5=Lambodhar | last6=Schneider | first6=Adriano De Bernardi | last7=Zimler | first7=Rebecca | last8=Talton | first8=James | last9=Cobb | first9=Ronald R. | journal=PLOS Neglected Tropical Diseases | volume=10 | issue=3 | pages=e0004530 | issn=1935-2735 | doi=10.1371/journal.pntd.0004530}}</ref> It is [[Mosquito-borne disease|spread]] by daytime-active ''[[Aedes]]'' mosquitoes, such as ''[[Aedes aegypti|A. aegypti]]'' and ''[[Aedes albopictus|A. albopictus]]''.ref name="MaloneHoman2016" Its name comes from the [[Zika Forest]] of Uganda, where the virus was first isolated in 1947.ref name="SikkaChattu2016"{{cite journal | url= http://www.jgid.org/text.asp?2016/8/1/3/176140 | title=The emergence of zika virus as a global health security threat: A review and a consensus statement of the INDUSEM Joint working Group (JWG) | date=11 February 2016 | last=Sikka | first=Veronica | last2=Chattu | first2=Vijay Kumar | last3=Popli | first3=Raaj K. | last4=Galwankar | first4=Sagar C. | last5=Kelkar | first5=Dhanashree | last6=Sawicki | first6=Stanley G. | last7=Stawicki | first7=Stanislaw P. | last8=Papadimos | first8=Thomas J. | journal=Journal of Global Infectious Diseases | volume=8 | issue=1 | pages=3\u201315 | issn=0974-8245 | doi=10.4103/0974-777X.176140 | display-authors=3}}</ref> Zika virus is related to the [[Dengue virus|dengue]], [[Yellow fever virus|yellow fever]], [[Japanese encephalitis]], and [[West Nile virus|West Nile]] viruses.ref name="SikkaChattu2016" Since the 1950s, it has been known to occur within a narrow equatorial belt from Africa to Asia. [[2007 Yap Islands Zika virus outbreak|From 2007]] to As of2016alt=2016, the virus spread eastward, [[2013\u20132014 Zika virus outbreaks in Oceania|across the Pacific Ocean]] to the Americas, where the [[2015\u201316 Zika virus epidemic]] reached [[pandemic]] levels.ref name="pandemic1"{{cite news |last1=Chastain |first1=Mary |title=National Institutes of Health: Zika Virus Is a \u2018Pandemic\u2019 |url= http://www.breitbart.com/national-security/2016/01/30/zika-virus-reaches-pandemic-levels/ |accessdate=13 February 2016 |work=[[Breitbart]] |date=30 January 2016}}</ref>unreliable sourcedate=August 2016<!-- Zika fever -->The infection, known as [[Zika fever]] or Zika virus disease, often causes no or only mild symptoms, similar to a very mild form of [[dengue fever]].ref name="MaloneHoman2016" While there is no specific treatment, [[paracetamol]] (acetaminophen) and rest may help with the symptoms.ref name="cdcsymptoms"{{cite web | url= http://www.cdc.gov/zika/symptoms/ | title=Symptoms, Diagnosis, & Treatment | work=Zika virus | publisher=[[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]] | date=3 March 2016 | accessdate=4 March 2016 | location=Atlanta}}</ref> As of2016, the illness cannot be prevented by medications or [[vaccine]]s.ref name="cdcsymptoms" Zika can also spread from a pregnant woman to her fetus. This can result in [[microcephaly]], severe brain malformations, and other birth defects.ref name=NEJM201604{{cite journal | last1=Rasmussen | first1=Sonja A. | last2=Jamieson | first2=Denise J. | last3=Honein | first3=Margaret A. | last4=Petersen | first4=Lyle R. | title=Zika Virus and Birth Defects \u2014 Reviewing the Evidence for Causality | journal=New England Journal of Medicine | date=13 April 2016 | doi=10.1056/NEJMsr1604338 | accessdate=15 April 2016 | url= http://www.nejm.org/doi/pdf/10.1056/NEJMsr1604338 | volume=374 | pages=1981\u20131987}}</ref>ref name=CDC2016Cause{{cite web | title=CDC Concludes Zika Causes Microcephaly and Other Birth Defects | url= http://www.cdc.gov/media/releases/2016/s0413-zika-microcephaly.html | website=CDC | accessdate=14 April 2016 | date=13 April 2016}}</ref> Zika infections in adults may result rarely in [[Guillain\u2013Barr\u00e9 syndrome]].ref name="WHO SitRep 7 Apr 2016"{{cite web | url= http://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/10665/204961/1/zikasitrep_7Apr2016_eng.pdf?ua=1 | title=Zika Virus Microcephaly And Guillain-Barr\u00e9 Syndrome Situation Report | publisher=World Health Organization | date=7 April 2016 | accessdate=8 April 2016}}</ref><!-- Prevention -->In January 2016, the United States [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]] issued travel guidance on affected countries, including the use of enhanced precautions, and guidelines for pregnant women including considering postponing travel.ref name="CDCCaribbean"{{cite web | url= http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/travel/notices/alert/zika-virus-caribbean | title=Zika Virus in the Caribbean | work=Travelers' Health: Travel Notices | publisher=Centers for Disease Control and Prevention | date=15 January 2016}}</ref>ref name="PetersenStaples2016"{{cite journal | first1=Emily E. | url= http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/65/wr/mm6502e1.htm | date=22 January 2016 | display-authors=3 | first2=J. Erin | first4=Marc | last1=Petersen | title=Interim Guidelines for Pregnant Women During a Zika Virus Outbreak \u2014 United States, 2016 | last2=Staples | last3=Meaney-Delman | first3=Dana | last4=Fischer | last5=Ellington | first5=Sascha R. | last6=Callaghan | first6=William M. | last7=Jamieson | first7=Denise J. | journal=MMWR. Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report | volume=65 | issue=2 | pages=30\u201333 | issn=0149-2195 | doi=10.15585/mmwr.mm6502e1| pmid=26796813 }}</ref> Other governments or health agencies also issued similar travel warnings,ref name="ITV22Jan2016"{{cite news | url= http://www.itv.com/news/2016-01-22/zika-virus-advice-for-those-planning-to-travel-to-outbreak-area | title=Zika virus: Advice for those planning to travel to outbreak areas | work=ITV Report | publisher=[[ITV News]] | date=22 January 2016 | accessdate=24 January 2016}}</ref>ref name="RTE22Jan2016"{{cite news | url= http://www.rte.ie/news/2016/0122/762119-el-salvador-zika-virus | title=Pregnant Irish women warned over Zika virus in central and South America | publisher=RT\u00c9 News | date=22 January 2016 | accessdate=23 January 2016}}</ref>ref name="BBC24Jan2016"{{cite news | url= http://www.bbc.com/news/world-latin-america-35394297 | title=Zika: Olympics plans announced by Rio authorities | publisher=BBC | date=24 January 2016 | accessdate=24 January 2016 | quote=The Rio de Janeiro authorities have announced plans to prevent the spread of the Zika virus during the Olympic Games later this year. \u2026 The US, Canada and EU health agencies have issued warnings saying pregnant women should avoid traveling to Brazil and other countries in the Americas which have registered cases of Zika.}}</ref> while Colombia, the Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, and Jamaica advised women to postpone getting pregnant until more is known about the risks.ref name=RTE22Jan2016 ref name="BBC23Jan2016"{{cite news | url= http://www.bbc.com/news/world-latin-america-35388842 | title=Zika virus triggers pregnancy delay calls | publisher=BBC | date=23 January 2016 | accessdate=23 January 2016}}</ref> The word is pronounced IPAc-en\u02c8zi\u02d0k\u0259,_\u02c8z\u026ak\u0259.ref name="Pronunciation "{{cite web | url= https://www.howtopronounce.com/zika/ | title=How to pronounce Zika | work=How To Pronounce}}</ref>ref name="eid14"{{cite journal | url= http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/20/6/et-2006_article | title=Etymologia: Zika Virus | date=June 2014 | journal=Emerging Infectious Diseases | volume=20 | issue=6 | page=1090 | doi=10.3201/eid2006.ET2006 | pmc=4036762 | pmid=24983096}}</ref>TOC limit3== Virology ==[[File:Zika virus video osmosis.webm|thumb|A video explanation of the Zika virus and of Zika fever]]The Zika virus belongs to the ''[[Flaviviridae]]'' family and the ''[[Flavivirus]]'' genus, and is thus related to the [[Dengue virus|dengue]], [[Yellow fever virus|yellow fever]], [[Japanese encephalitis]], and [[West Nile virus|West Nile]] viruses. Like other flaviviruses, Zika virus is [[Viral envelope|enveloped]] and [[icosahedral]] and has a nonsegmented, single-stranded, 10 [[kilobase]] [[Sense (molecular biology)|positive-sense]] [[RNA]] genome. It is most closely related to the [[Spondweni virus]] and is one of the two viruses in the Spondweni virus [[clade]].ref name="Fields"{{cite book | url= https://books.google.com/books?id=5O0somr0w18C | title=Fields Virology | publisher=Lippincott Williams & Wilkins | last=Knipe | first=David M. | last2=Howley | first2=Peter M. | year=2007 | edition=5th | pages=1156, 1199 | isbn=978-0-7817-6060-7}}</ref>ref name="FayeFreire2014"{{cite journal |last1=Faye |first1=Oumar | last2=Freire | first2=Caio C. M. | last3=Iamarino | first3=Atila | last4=Faye | first4=Ousmane | last5=de Oliveira | first5=Juliana Velasco C. | last6=Diallo | first6=Mawlouth | last7=Zanotto | first7=Paolo M. A. | date=9 January 2014 |title=Molecular Evolution of Zika Virus during Its Emergence in the 20th Century | last8=Sall | first8=Amadou Alpha | last9=Bird | first9=Brian | journal=PLoS Neglected Tropical Diseases | volume=8 | issue=1 | pages=e2636 | doi=10.1371/journal.pntd.0002636 | pmc=3888466 | pmid=24421913}}</ref>ref{{cite journal |last1=Cao-Lormeau |first1=VM |last2=Roche |first2=C |last3=Teissier |first3=A |last4=Robin |first4=E |last5=Berry |first5=AL |last6=Mallet |first6=HP |last7=Sall |first7=AA |last8=Musso |first8=D. |title=Zika virus, French polynesia, South pacific, 2013. |journal=Emerg Infect Dis. |date= June 2014 |volume=20 |issue=6 |pages=1085\u20136 |doi=10.3201/eid2006.140138 |pmid=24856001 |pmc=4036769}}</ref>ref name="Hayes2009" ref name="KunoChang2007"{{cite journal | url= http://link.springer.com/article/10.1007%2Fs00705-006-0903-z | title=Full-length sequencing and genomic characterization of Bagaza, Kedougou, and Zika viruses | date=1 January 2007 | last=Kuno | first=G. | last2=Chang | first2=G.-J. J. | journal=Archives of Virology | volume=152 | issue=4 | pages=687\u2013696 | doi=10.1007/s00705-006-0903-z | pmid=17195954}}</ref>[[File:197-Zika Virus-ZikaVirus.tif|thumb|right|Cross-section of Zika virus, with capsid layer (pink), membrane layer (purple), and RNA genome (yellow)ref name="Goodsell_2016"{{cite web|last1=Goodsell|first1=D.S.|title=Zika Virus|url= https://doi.org/10.2210/rcsb_pdb/mom_2016_5|website=RCSB Protein Data Bank|publisher=Research Collaboratory for Structural Bioinformatics (RCSB)|accessdate=6 June 2016|doi=10.2210/rcsb_pdb/mom_2016_5}}</ref>]]A [[positive-sense RNA]] genome can be directly translated into viral proteins. In other flaviviruses, such as the similarly sized West Nile virus, the RNA genome genes encode seven nonstructural proteins and three structural proteins. The structural proteins encapsulate the virus. The replicated RNA strand is held within a [[nucleocapsid]] formed from 12-kDa protein blocks; the capsid is contained within a host-derived membrane modified with two viral glycoproteins. Replication of the viral genome would first require creation of an anti-sense nucleotide strand.ref name="Pierson2012"{{cite journal|last1=Pierson|first1=TC|last2=Diamond|first2=MS|title=Degrees of maturity: the complex structure and biology of flaviviruses.|journal=Current opinion in virology|date=April 2012|volume=2|issue=2|pages=168\u201375|pmid=22445964|doi=10.1016/j.coviro.2012.02.011|pmc=3715965}}</ref>There are two lineages of Zika: the African lineage and the Asian lineage.ref name="EnfissiCodrington2016"{{cite journal | url= http://www.thelancet.com/journals/lancet/article/PIIS0140-6736(16)00003-9 | title=Zika virus genome from the Americas | date=16 January 2016 | display-authors=3 | last=Enfissi | first=Antoine | last2=Codrington | first2=John | last3=Roosblad | first3=Jimmy | last4=Kazanji | first4=Mirdad | last5=Rousset | first5=Dominique | journal=Lancet | volume=387 | issue=10015 | pages=227\u20138 | doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(16)00003-9 | pmid=26775124}}</ref> Phylogenetic studies indicate that the virus spreading in the Americas is 89% identical to African genotypes, but is most closely related to the Asian strain that circulated in [[French Polynesian Zika virus outbreak|French Polynesia during the 2013ndash2014 outbreak]].ref name=EnfissiCodrington2016 ref name="ZanlucaMelo2015"{{cite journal | title=First report of autochthonous transmission of Zika virus in Brazil | date=June 2015 | display-authors=3 | first1=Camila | last2=Melo | first2=Vanessa Campos Andrade de | last3=Mosimann | first3=Ana Luiza Pamplona | last4=Santos | first4=Glauco Igor Viana dos | last5=Santos | first5=Claudia Nunes Duarte dos | last6=Luz | first6=Kleber | journal=Mem\u00f3rias do Instituto Oswaldo Cruz | last1=Zanluca | volume=110 | issue=4 | pages=569\u2013572 | issn=1678-8060 | doi=10.1590/0074-02760150192 | pmid=26061233 | pmc=4501423}}</ref>ref name="LanciottiLambert2016"{{cite journal | first1=Robert S. | last1=Lanciotti | url= http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/22/5/16-0065_article.htm | title=Phylogeny of Zika Virus in Western Hemisphere, 2015 | last2=Lambert | first2=Amy J. | last3=Holodniy | first3=Mark | last4=Saavedra | first4=Sonia | last5=del Carmen Castillo Signor | first5=Leticia | journal=Emerging Infectious Diseases | year=2016 | volume=22 | issue=5 | pages=933\u20135 | issn=1080-6040 | doi=10.3201/eid2205.160065 | pmid=27088323 | display-authors=3 | pmc=4861537}}</ref>== Transmission ==The vertebrate hosts of the virus were primarily [[monkey]]s in a so-called [[enzootic]] mosquito-monkey-mosquito cycle, with only occasional transmission to humans. Before the current [[pandemic]] began in 2007, Zika "rarely caused recognized 'spillover' infections in humans, even in highly enzootic areas". Infrequently, however, other [[arbovirus]]es have become established as a human disease and spread in a mosquito\u2013human\u2013mosquito cycle, like the yellow fever virus and the dengue fever virus (both flaviviruses), and the [[chikungunya]] virus (a [[togavirus]]).ref name="FauciMorens2016"{{cite journal | url= http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMp1600297 | title=Zika Virus in the Americas \u2013 Yet Another Arbovirus Threat | date=14 January 2016 | last=Fauci | first=Anthony S. | last2=Morens | first2=David M. | journal=New England Journal of Medicine | volume=374 | issue=2 | pages=601\u20134 | doi=10.1056/NEJMp1600297 | pmid=26761185}}</ref> Though the reason for the pandemic is unknown, dengue, a related arbovirus that infects the same [[Mosquito-borne disease|species of mosquito vectors]], is known in particular to be intensified by [[urbanization]] and [[globalization]].ref{{cite journal | pmc = 3317603 | pmid=22500131 | doi=10.2149/tmh.2011-S05 | volume=39 | title=Dengue, Urbanization and Globalization: The Unholy Trinity of the 21(st) Century | year=2011 | journal=Trop Med Health | pages=3\u201311 | last1 = Gubler | first1 = DJ}}</ref>=== Mosquito ===[[File:Global Aedes aegypti distribution (e08347).png|alt=Aedes aegypti predicted distribution|thumb|right|Global ''[[Aedes aegypti]]'' predicted distribution. The map depicts the probability of occurrence (blue=none, red=highest occurrence).]]Zika is primarily spread by the female ''[[Aedes aegypti]]'' mosquito, which is active mostly in the daytime, although researchers have found the virus in common Culex house mosquitoes as well.ref name="CNN"{{cite web | url= http://www.cnn.com/2016/07/22/health/zika-culex-mosquito-brazil/ | title=Zika virus found in common house mosquitoes | accessdate=23 July 2016}}</ref> The mosquitos must feed on blood in order to lay eggs.ref name="CDCDengue"{{cite web | url= http://www.cdc.gov/dengue/resources/30Jan2012/aegyptifactsheet.pdf | title=Dengue and the ''Aedes aegypti'' mosquito | work=Dengue Branch | publisher=Centers for Disease Control and Prevention | accessdate=2 February 2012}}</ref>rp2 The virus has also been isolated from a number of [[arboreal]] mosquito species in the ''[[Aedes]]'' genus, such as ''[[Aedes africanus|A. africanus]]'', ''[[Aedes apicoargenteus|A. apicoargenteus]]'', ''[[Aedes furcifer|A. furcifer]]'', ''[[Aedes hensilli|A. hensilli]]'', ''[[Aedes luteocephalus|A. luteocephalus]]'' and ''[[Aedes vittatus|A. vittatus]]'', with an [[extrinsic incubation period]] in mosquitoes of about 10 days.ref name="Hayes2009"{{cite journal | first1=Edward B. | last1=Hayes | url= http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/15/9/09-0442_article | title=Zika Virus Outside Africa | date=September 2009 | journal=Emerging Infectious Diseases | volume=15 | issue=9 | pages=1347\u20131350 | issn=1080-6040 | doi=10.3201/eid1509.090442 | pmid=19788800| pmc=2819875 }}</ref>The true extent of the vectors is still unknown. Zika has been detected in many more species of ''Aedes'', along with ''Anopheles coustani, Mansonia uniformis'', and ''[[Culex perfuscus]]'', although this alone does not incriminate them as a vector.ref name="Ayres2016"{{cite journal | first1=Const\u00e2ncia F J | last1=Ayres | url= http://www.thelancet.com/journals/laninf/article/PIIS1473-3099(16)00073-6/abstract | title=Identification of Zika virus vectors and implications for control | journal=The Lancet Infectious Diseases | volume=16 | issue=3 | pages=278\u2013279 | issn=1473-3099 | doi=10.1016/S1473-3099(16)00073-6 | pmid=26852727 | date=4 February 2016}}</ref>Transmission by ''[[Aedes albopictus|A. albopictus]]'', the tiger mosquito, was reported from a 2007 urban outbreak in Gabon where it had newly invaded the country and become the primary vector for the concomitant [[chikungunya]] and dengue virus outbreaks.ref name="CharrelGrard2014"{{cite journal |url= http://journals.plos.org/plosntds/article?id=10.1371/journal.pntd.0002681 | title=Zika Virus in Gabon (Central Africa) \u2013 2007: A New Threat from Aedes albopictus? | first1=Remi | last1=Charrel | last2=Grard | first2=Gilda | last3=Caron | first3=M\u00e9lanie | last4=Mombo | first4=Illich Manfred | last5=Nkoghe | first5=Dieudonn\u00e9 | last6=Mboui Ondo | first6=Statiana | last7=Jiolle | first7=Davy | last8=Fontenille | first8=Didier | last9=Paupy | first9=Christophe | first10=Eric Maurice | last10=Leroy | journal=PLoS Neglected Tropical Diseases | volume=8 | issue=2 | pages=e2681 | issn=1935-2735 | doi=10.1371/journal.pntd.0002681 | pmid=24516683 | date=6 February 2014 | display-authors=3 | pmc=3916288}}</ref> There is concern for [[wikt:autochthonous|autochthonous]] infections in [[urban areas]] of European countries infested by ''A. albopictus'' because the first two cases of laboratory-confirmed Zika infections imported into Italy were reported from [[wikt:viraemia|viremic]] travelers returning from French Polynesia.ref name="ZammarchiStella2015"{{cite journal | url= http://www.journalofclinicalvirology.com/article/S1386-6532(14)00467-3/abstract | date=February 2015 | display-authors=3 | first1=Lorenzo | first10=Alessandro | first11=Jonas | first2=Giulia | first6=Stephan | last1=Zammarchi | last10=Bartoloni | last11=Schmidt-Chanasit | title=Zika virus infections imported to Italy: Clinical, immunological and virological findings, and public health implications | last2=Stella | last3=Mantella | first3=Antonia | last4=Bartolozzi | first4=Dario | last5=Tappe | first5=Dennis | last6=G\u00fcnther | last7=Oestereich | first7=Lisa | last8=Cadar | first8=Daniel | last9=Mu\u00f1oz-Fontela | first9=C\u00e9sar | journal=Journal of Clinical Virology | volume=63 | pages=32\u201335 | issn=1386-6532 | doi=10.1016/j.jcv.2014.12.005| pmid=25600600 }}</ref>The potential societal risk of Zika can be delimited by the distribution of the mosquito species that transmit it. The global distribution of the most cited carrier of Zika, ''A. aegypti'', is expanding due to global trade and travel.ref name="KraemerSinka2015"{{cite journal | last=Kraemer | first=Moritz U. G. | last2=Sinka | first2=Marianne E. | last3=Duda | first3=Kirsten A. | last4=Mylne | first4=Adrian Q. N. | last5=Shearer | first5=Freya M. | last6=Barker | first6=Christopher M. | last7=Moore | first7=Chester G. | last8=Carvalho | first8=Roberta G. | last9=Coelho | first9=Giovanini E. | doi=10.7554/eLife.08347 | pmc=4493616 | url= http://elifesciences.org/content/4/e08347 | title=The global distribution of the arbovirus vectors ''Aedes aegypti'' and ''Ae. albopictus'' | date=7 July 2015 | journal=ELife | volume=4 | pages=e08347 | pmid=26126267 | display-authors=3}}</ref> ''A. aegypti'' distribution is now the most extensive ever recorded \u2013 across all continents including North America and even the European periphery ([[Madeira]], the Netherlands, and the northeastern [[Black Sea]] coast).ref name="ECDCAedes"{{cite web | access-date=25 January 2016 | url= http://ecdc.europa.eu/en/healthtopics/vectors/mosquitoes/Pages/aedes-aegypti.aspx | title=''Aedes aegypti'' | work=Health Topics:Vectors:Mosquitos| publisher=European Centre for Disease Protection and Control }}</ref> A mosquito population capable of carrying Zika has been found in a [[Capitol Hill]] neighborhood of Washington, D. C., and genetic evidence suggests they survived at least four consecutive winters in the region. The study authors conclude that mosquitos are adapting for persistence in a northern climate.ref name="NotreDame"{{cite news | url= http://news.nd.edu/news/64004-mosquitos-capable-of-carrying-zika-virus-found-in-washington-dc | title=Mosquitoes capable of carrying Zika virus found in Washington, D.C. | work=Notre Dame News | publisher=University of Notre Dame | date=26 January 2016 | first1=Sarah | last2=Collins | first2=Brittany | last1=Craig}}</ref> The Zika virus appears to be contagious via mosquitoes for around a week after infection. The virus is thought to be infectious for a longer period of time after infection (2 weeks) when transmitted via semen.ref{{Cite web|url=http://www.bbc.com/news/health-35370848|title=Zika outbreak: What you need to know - BBC News|language=en-GB|access-date=2016-07-31}}</ref>ref{{Cite web|url=http://www.totalorlando.com/blog/avoid-mosquito-bites-florida/|title=How to Avoid Mosquito Bites in Florida|date=2013-06-10|language=en-US|access-date=2016-07-31}}</ref>Since 2015, news reports have drawn attention to the spread of Zika in Latin America and the Caribbean.ref name="TRF22Jan2016"{{cite news | access-date=26 January 2016 | url= http://news.trust.org/item/20160122152242-yxsmt/ | title=FACTBOX \u2013 Zika virus spreads rapidly through Latin America, Caribbean | work=Thomson Reuters Foundation News | date=22 January 2016 | author=Moloney, Anastasia}}</ref> The countries and territories that have been identified by the [[Pan American Health Organisation]] as having experienced "local Zika virus transmission" are Barbados, Bolivia, Brazil, Colombia, the Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, French Guiana, Guadeloupe, Guatemala, Guyana, Haiti, Honduras, Martinique, Mexico, Panama, Paraguay, Puerto Rico, Saint Martin, Suriname, and Venezuela.ref name="PAHO18Jan2016"{{cite web | access-date=25 January 2016 | url= http://www.paho.org/hq/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=11574%253A2016-as-the-zika-virus-spreads-paho-advises-countries-to-monitor-and-report-birth-anomalies-suspected-complications-of-virus&Itemid=1926&lang=en | title=As the Zika virus spreads, PAHO advises countries to monitor and report birth anomalies and other suspected complications of the virus | work=Media Center | publisher=Pan American Health Organization | date=18 January 2016 | last=Mitchell | first=Cristina}}</ref>ref name="PAHO2Feb2016"{{cite web | url= http://www.paho.org/hq/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=11605%3A2016-paho-statement-on-zika-transmission-prevention-&catid=8444%3Anews&Itemid=41716&lang=en | title=PAHO Statement on Zika Virus Transmission and Prevention | work=Zika website | publisher=Pan American Health Organization | date=2 February 2016 | last=Mitchell | first=Cristina}}</ref>ref name="CNN5Things"{{cite news |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2016/01/26/health/zika-what-you-need-to-know |title=5 things you need to know about Zika |publisher=CNN |date=24 February 2016 }}</ref>Research into its ecological niche suggests that Zika may be influenced to a greater degree by changes in precipitation and temperature than Dengue, making it more likely to be confined to tropical areas. However, rising global temperatures would allow for the disease vector to expand their range further north, allowing Zika to follow.refColin Carlson, Eric Dougherty, Wayne Getz. An ecological assessment of the pandemic threat of Zika virus. bioRxiv 040386; {{DOI|10.1101/040386}}</ref>=== Sexual ===Zika can be transmitted from a man or a woman to their sexual partners.ref name="OsterRussell2016"{{cite journal | first1=Alexandra M. | last1=Oster | url= http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/65/wr/mm6512e3.htm | title=Update: Interim Guidance for Prevention of Sexual Transmission of Zika Virus | date=1 April 2016 | last2=Russell | first2=Kate | last3=Stryker | first3=Jo Ellen | last4=Friedman | first4=Allison | last5=Kachur | first5=Rachel E. | last6=Petersen | first6=Emily E. | last7=Jamieson | first7=Denise J. | last8=Cohn | first8=Amanda C. | last9=Brooks | first9=John T. | journal=MMWR. Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report | volume=65 | issue=12 | pages=323\u2013325 | doi=10.15585/mmwr.mm6512e3 | pmid=27032078 | display-authors=3}}</ref>ref{{Cite web| url=http://www.msn.com/en-us/sports/olympics/who-chief-going-to-the-olympics-says-zika-risk-low/ar-BBv1c2x| title=WHO chief going to the Olympics, says Zika risk low| website=www.msn.com|access-date=2016-07-30| quote=According to [[Margaret Chan]], the director of the WHO, "Of course, we also have learnt from the latest evidence it's not just infected men who can pass the disease to their sex partners. There was a case of a lady passing the disease to a man, so it can go both directions."}}</ref> As of April 2016 sexual transmission of Zika has been documented in six countries \u2013 Argentina, Chile, France, Italy, New Zealand and the United States \u2013 during the 2015 outbreak.ref name="WHO SitRep 7 Apr 2016" In 2014, Zika capable of growth in lab culture was found in the semen of a man at least two weeks (and possibly up to 10 weeks) after he fell ill with Zika fever.ref name="OsterBrooks2016"{{cite journal | display-authors=3 | first1=Alexandra M. | url= http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/65/wr/mm6505e1er.htm | title=Interim Guidelines for Prevention of Sexual Transmission of Zika Virus | date=12 February 2016 | last2=Brooks | first2=John T. | last3=Stryker | first3=Jo Ellen | last4=Kachur | first4=Rachel E. | last5=Mead | first5=Paul | last6=Pesik | first6=Nicki T. | last7=Petersen | first7=Lyle R. | journal=Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report | issue=5 | last1=Oster | volume=65 | pages=120\u2013121 | doi=10.15585/mmwr.mm6505e1 | pmid=26866485}}</ref>ref name="MussoRoche2015"{{cite journal | url= http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/21/2/14-1363_article | title=Potential Sexual Transmission of Zika Virus | first1=Didier | last1=Musso | last2=Roche | first2=Claudine | last3=Robin | first3=Emilie | last4=Nhan | first4=Tuxuan | last5=Teissier | first5=Anita | last6=Cao-Lormeau | first6=Van-Mai | journal=Emerging Infectious Diseases | volume=21 | issue=2 | pages=359\u2013361 | issn=1080-6040 | doi=10.3201/eid2102.141363 | pmid=25625872 | date=February 2015 | pmc=4313657}}</ref> In 2011 a study found that a United States biologist who had been bitten many times while studying mosquitoes in Senegal developed symptoms six days after returning home in August 2008, but not before having unprotected intercourse with his wife, who had not been outside the US since 2008. Both husband and wife were confirmed to have Zika antibodies, raising awareness of the possibility of sexual transmission.ref name="OsterBrooks2016" ref name="FoyKobylinski2011"{{cite journal | first1=Brian D. | last1=Foy | url= http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/17/5/10-1939_article | title=Probable Non\u2013Vector-borne Transmission of Zika Virus, Colorado, USA | last2=Kobylinski | first2=Kevin C. | last3=Foy | first3=Joy L. Chilson | last4=Blitvich | first4=Bradley J. | last5=Travassos da Rosa | first5=Amelia | last6=Haddow | first6=Andrew D. | last7=Lanciotti | first7=Robert S. | last8=Tesh | first8=Robert B. | journal=Emerging Infectious Diseases | year=2011 | volume=17 | issue=5 | pages=880\u2013882 | issn=1080-6040 | doi=10.3201/eid1705.101939 | pmc=3321795 | pmid=21529401 | display-authors=3}}</ref> In early February 2016, the [[Dallas County, Texas|Dallas County]] Health and Human Services department reported that a man from Texas who had not travelled abroad had been infected after his male monogamous sexual partner had anal penetrative sex with him one day before and one day after onset of symptoms.ref name="OsterBrooks2016" ref name="Dallas"{{cite web | access-date=6 February 2016 | url= http://www.dallascounty.org/department/hhs/press/documents/PR2-2-16DCHHSReportsFirstCaseofZikaVirusThroughSexualTransmission.pdf?dom=pscau&src=syn | title=DCHHS Reports First Zika Virus Case in Dallas County Acquired Through Sexual Transmission | publisher=Dallas County Health and Human Services | date=2 February 2016}}</ref>ref{{cite journal|url=http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/65/wr/mm6514a3.htm?s_cid=mm6514a3_w|title=Male-to-Male Sexual Transmission of Zika Virus \u2014 Texas, January 2016|journal=CDC Weekly|date=2016-04-15|volume=65|number=14|pages=372\u20134|doi=10.15585/mmwr.mm6514a3}}</ref> As of February 2016, fourteen additional cases of possible sexual transmission have been under investigation, but it remained unknown whether women can transmit Zika to their sexual partners.ref name="CDC23Feb2016"{{cite web | url= http://www.cdc.gov/media/releases/2016/s0223-zika-guidance.html | title=CDC encourages following guidance to prevent sexual transmission of Zika virus | work=CDC Newsroom Releases | publisher=Centers for Disease Control and Prevention | date=23 February 2016}}</ref> At that time, the understanding of the "incidence and duration of shedding in the male genitourinary tract [was] limited to one case report." Therefore, the United States [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]] (CDC) interim guideline recommended against testing men for purposes of assessing the risk of sexual tranmission.ref name="OsterBrooks2016" In March 2016, the CDC updated its recommendations about length of precautions for couples, and advised that heterosexual couples with men who have confirmed Zika fever or symptoms of Zika should consider using condoms or not having penetrative sex (i.e., vaginal intercourse, anal intercourse, or fellatio) for at least 6 months after symptoms begin. This includes men who live in\u2014and men who traveled to\u2014areas with Zika. Couples with men who traveled to an area with Zika, but did not develop symptoms of Zika, should consider using condoms or not having sex for at least 8 weeks after their return in order to minimize risk. Couples with men who live in an area with Zika, but have not developed symptoms, might consider using condoms or not having sex while there is active Zika transmission in the area.ref name="PetersenPolen2016"{{cite journal | first1=Emily E. | first10=Mateusz P. | first11=Ann M. | first12=Jeanne | first13=John T. | first14=Dmitry | first15=Julie | first16=Jorge | first17=Matthew | first18=Christine K. | first19=Margaret A. | first20=Maria | first21=Denise J. | first22=Sonja A. | last1=Petersen | last10=Karwowski | last11=Powers | last12=Bertolli | last13=Brooks | last14=Kissin | last15=Villanueva | last16=Mu\u00f1oz-Jordan | last17=Kuehnert | last18=Olson | last19=Honein | last2=Polen | first2=Kara N.D. | last20=Rivera | last21=Jamieson | last22=Rasmussen | url= http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/65/wr/mm6512e2er.htm?s_cid=mm6512e2er_w | title=Update: Interim Guidance for Health Care Providers Caring for Women of Reproductive Age with Possible Zika Virus Exposure \u2014 United States, 2016 | last3=Meaney-Delman | first3=Dana | last4=Ellington | first4=Sascha R. | last5=Oduyebo | first5=Titilope | last6=Cohn | first6=Amanda | last7=Oster | first7=Alexandra M. | last8=Russell | first8=Kate | last9=Kawwass | first9=Jennifer F. | journal=MMWR. Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report | volume=65 | issue=12 | issn=0149-2195 | doi=10.15585/mmwr.mm6512e2er | date=25 March 2016 | display-authors=3}}</ref>=== Pregnancy ===The Zika virus can spread from an infected mother to her fetus during pregnancy or at delivery.ref name="CDCZikaTrans"{{cite web | url= http://www.cdc.gov/zika/transmission/index.html | title=CDC Zika: Transmission | publisher=U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention | date=15 April 2016 | accessdate=17 April 2016}}</ref>=== Blood transfusion ===As of April 2016, two cases of Zika transmission through [[blood transfusion]]s have been reported globally, both from Brazil,ref name="VasquezSapiano2016"{{cite journal | first1=Amber M. | last1=Vasquez | url= http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/65/wr/mm6514e1.htm?s_cid=mm6514e1_e | title=Survey of Blood Collection Centers and Implementation of Guidance for Prevention of Transfusion-Transmitted Zika Virus Infection \u2014 Puerto Rico, 2016 | last2=Sapiano | first2=Mathew R.P. | last3=Basavaraju | first3=Sridhar V. | last4=Kuehnert | first4=Matthew J. | last5=Rivera-Garcia | first5=Brenda | journal=MMWR. Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report | year=2016 | volume=65 | issue=14 | pages=375\u2013378 | issn=0149-2195 | doi=10.15585/mmwr.mm6514e1 | pmid=27078190 | display-authors=3}}</ref> after which the US [[Food and Drug Administration]] (FDA) recommended screening [[blood donation|blood donor]]s and deferring high-risk donors for 4 weeks.ref name="FDABloodDonors"{{cite web | url= http://www.fda.gov/downloads/BiologicsBloodVaccines/GuidanceComplianceRegulatoryInformation/Guidances/Blood/UCM486360.pdf | title=Recommendations for Donor Screening, Deferral, and Product Management to Reduce the Risk of Transfusion- Transmission of Zika Virus | publisher=[[Food and Drug Administration]] | date=February 2016 | format=PDF}}</ref>ref name="ECDC25May2015"{{cite web | url= http://ecdc.europa.eu/en/publications/Publications/rapid-risk-assessment-Zika%20virus-south-america-Brazil-2015.pdf | title=Zika virus infection outbreak, Brazil and the Pacific region | work=Rapid Risk Assessments | publisher=[[European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control]] | date=25 May 2015 | accessdate=12 February 2016 | location=Stockholm | pages=4\u20135}}</ref> A potential risk had been suspected based on a blood-donor screening study during the French Polynesian Zika outbreak, in which 2.8% (42) of donors from November 2013 and February 2014 tested positive for Zika RNA and were all asymptomatic at the time of blood donation. Eleven of the positive donors reported symptoms of Zika fever after their donation, but only three of 34 samples grew in culture.ref name="MussoNhan2014"{{cite journal | first1=D | last1=Musso | url= http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=20761 | title=Potential for Zika virus transmission through blood transfusion demonstrated during an outbreak in French Polynesia, November 2013 to February 2014 | date=10 April 2014 | last2=Nhan | first2=T | last3=Robin | first3=E | last4=Roche | first4=C | last5=Bierlaire | first5=D | last6=Zisou | first6=K | last7=Shan Yan | first7=A | last8=Cao-Lormeau | first8=VM | last9=Broult | first9=J | journal=[[Eurosurveillance]] | volume=19 | issue=14 | pmid=24739982 | display-authors=3}}</ref>== Pathogenesis ==Zika virus replicates in the mosquito's midgut epithelial cells and then its salivary gland cells. After 5\u201310 days, the virus can be found in the mosquito\u2019s saliva, which can then infect humans. If the mosquito\u2019s saliva is inoculated into human skin, the virus can infect epidermal keratinocytes, skin fibroblasts in the skin and the Langerhans cells. The pathogenesis of the virus is hypothesized to continue with a spread to [[lymph node]]s and the bloodstream.ref name="Fields" ref name="ChanChoi2016"{{cite journal | first1=Jasper F.W. | last1=Chan | url=http://www.journalofinfection.com/article/S0163-4453(16)00061-X/abstract | title=Zika fever and congenital Zika syndrome: An unexpected emerging arboviral disease | last2=Choi | first2=Garnet K.Y. | last3=Yip | first3=Cyril C.Y. | last4=Cheng | first4=Vincent C.C. | last5=Yuen | first5=Kwok-Yung | journal=Journal of Infection | volume=72 | issue=5 | pages=507\u201324 | year=2016 | issn=0163-4453 | doi=10.1016/j.jinf.2016.02.011 | pmid=26940504 | display-authors=3}}</ref> Flaviviruses generally replicate in the [[cytoplasm]], but Zika antigens have been found in infected cell nuclei.ref name="BuckleyGould1988"{{cite journal | first1=A. | url= http://jgv.microbiologyresearch.org/content/journal/jgv/10.1099/0022-1317-69-8-1913 | first2=E. A. | journal=Journal of General Virology | last1=Buckley | title=Detection of Virus-specific Antigen in the Nuclei or Nucleoli of Cells Infected with Zika or Langat Virus | last2=Gould | year=1988 | volume=69 | issue=8 | pages=1913\u20131920 | issn=0022-1317 | doi=10.1099/0022-1317-69-8-1913 | pmid=2841406}}</ref>== Zika fever ==Main articleZika fever[[File:Zika.Virus.Rash.Arm.2014.jpg|thumb|right|Rash on an arm due to Zika]]<!-- Definition and symptoms -->Zika fever (also known as Zika virus disease) is an illness caused by the Zika virus.ref name="WHO2016Jan"{{cite web | url= http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/zika/en/ | title=Zika virus | publisher=World Health Organization | date=January 2016 | accessdate=3 February 2016}}</ref> Most cases have no symptoms, but when present they are usually mild and can resemble [[dengue fever]].ref name="WHO2016Jan" ref name="ecdc1"{{cite web | url= http://ecdc.europa.eu/en/healthtopics/zika_virus_infection/factsheet-health-professionals/Pages/factsheet_health_professionals.aspx | title=Factsheet for health professionals | work=Zika virus infection | publisher=European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control | accessdate=22 December 2015}}</ref> Symptoms may include [[fever]], [[conjunctivitis|red eyes]], [[arthralgia|joint pain]], headache, and a [[maculopapular rash]].ref name=WHO2016Janref name=Ann2016ref name="Musso14"{{cite journal | url= http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S1198743X1465391X | title=Rapid spread of emerging Zika virus in the Pacific area | last=Musso | first=D. | last2=Nilles | first2=E.J. | last3=Cao-Lormeau | first3=V.-M. | journal=Clinical Microbiology and Infection | year=2014 | volume=20 | issue=10 | pages=O595\u20136 | doi=10.1111/1469-0691.12707 | pmid=24909208}}</ref> Symptoms generally last less than seven days.ref name=Ann2016 It has not caused any reported deaths during the initial infection.ref name="ecdc1"<!--NOTE: IT IS NO LONGER "SUSPECTED" THAT ZIKA CAUSES MICROCEPHALY ETC., IT IS A FACT ACCEPTED BY WHO AND THE CDC. PLEASE EDIT ACCORDINGLY.--> Infection during pregnancy causes [[microcephaly]] and other brain malformations in some babies.ref name=NEJM201604ref name="CDC2016Cause" Infection in adults has been linked to [[Guillain\u2013Barr\u00e9 syndrome]] (GBS).ref name="ecdc1"<!-- Cause and diagnosis -->Diagnosis is by testing the blood, urine, or saliva for the presence of Zika virus [[RNA]] when the person is sick.ref name=WHO2016Janref name=Ann2016<!-- Prevention and treatment -->Prevention involves decreasing mosquito bites in areas where the disease occurs and proper use of condoms.ref name="Ann2016"{{cite journal | first1=Lin H. | last1=Chen | url= http://annals.org/article.aspx?articleid=2486362 | title=Zika Virus: Rapid Spread in the Western Hemisphere | last2=Hamer | first2=Davidson H. | journal=Annals of Internal Medicine | year=2016 | issn=0003-4819 | doi=10.7326/M16-0150 | pmid=26832396 | volume=164 | issue=9 | pages=613}}</ref>ref name=CDC2016{{cite journal|last1=Oster|first1=Alexandra M.|last2=Russell|first2=Kate|last3=Stryker|first3=Jo Ellen|last4=Friedman|first4=Allison|last5=Kachur|first5=Rachel E.|last6=Petersen|first6=Emily E.|last7=Jamieson|first7=Denise J.|last8=Cohn|first8=Amanda C.|last9=Brooks|first9=John T.|title=Update: Interim Guidance for Prevention of Sexual Transmission of Zika Virus \u2014 United States, 2016|journal=MMWR. Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report|date=1 April 2016|volume=65|issue=12|pages=323\u2013325|doi=10.15585/mmwr.mm6512e3|pmid = 27032078}}</ref> Efforts to prevent bites include the use of [[insect repellent]], covering much of the body with clothing, [[mosquito nets]], and getting rid of standing water where mosquitoes reproduce.ref name=WHO2016Jan There is no effective [[vaccine]].ref name=Ann2016 Health officials recommended that women in areas affected by the [[Zika virus outbreak (2015\u2013present)|2015\u201316 Zika outbreak]] consider putting off pregnancy and that pregnant women not travel to these areas.ref name=Ann2016ref name="cnn1"{{cite news | url= http://www.cnn.com/2015/12/23/health/brazil-zika-pregnancy-warning/index.html | title=Brazil warns against pregnancy due to spreading virus | publisher=CNN | date=24 December 2015 | accessdate=24 December 2015}}</ref> While there is no specific treatment, [[paracetamol]] (acetaminophen) and rest may help with the symptoms.ref name="cdcsymptoms"ref name=Ann2016 Admission to hospital is rarely necessary.ref name="ecdc1"== Vaccine development ==Effective [[vaccine]]s have existed for several viruses of the [[flaviviridae]] family, namely [[yellow fever vaccine]], [[Japanese encephalitis vaccine]], and [[tick-borne encephalitis vaccine]], since the 1930s, and for dengue fever vaccine since the mid-2010s.ref name="WHO14Dec2015"{{cite web | url= http://www.who.int/immunization/research/development/dengue_vaccines/en | title=Dengue vaccine research | work=Immunization, Vaccines and Biologicals | publisher=World Health Organization | date=14 December 2015}}</ref>ref name="BennettDolin2014"{{cite book | url= https://books.google.com/books?id=BseNCgAAQBAJ | title=Principles and Practice of Infectious Diseases | publisher=Elsevier Health Sciences | date=2014 | last=Bennett | first=John E. | last2=Dolin | first2=Raphael | last3=Blaser | first3=Martin J. | page=1881 | isbn=978-1-4557-4801-3}}</ref>ref name="SciAm30Dec2015"{{cite news | access-date=28 January 2016 | url= http://www.scientificamerican.com/article/first-dengue-fever-vaccine-gets-green-light-in-3-countries | title=First Dengue Fever Vaccine Gets Green Light in 3 Countries | work=Scientific American | date=30 December 2016 | last=Maron | first=Dina Fine}}</ref> [[World Health Organization]] (WHO) experts have suggested that the priority should be to develop [[inactivated vaccine]]s and other non-live vaccines, which are safe to use in pregnant women and those of childbearing age.ref name="WHO9Mar2016"{{cite web | url= http://www.who.int/mediacentre/news/notes/2016/research-development-zika/en/ | title=WHO and experts prioritize vaccines, diagnostics and innovative vector control tools for Zika R&D | publisher=World Health Organization | date=9 March 2016 | accessdate=13 March 2016}}</ref>The [[National Institutes of Health|NIH]] [[Vaccine Research Center]] (U.S.) began work towards developing a vaccine for Zika per a January 2016 report.ref name="USN22Jan2016"{{cite news | access-date=28 January 2016 | url= http://www.usnews.com/news/articles/2016-01-22/vaccine-efforts-underway-as-zika-virus-spreads | title=Vaccine Efforts Underway as Zika Virus Spreads | work=US News & World Report | date=22 January 2016 | last=Sternberg | first=Steve}}</ref>[[Bharat Biotech International]] (India) reported in early February 2016, that it was working on vaccines for Zikaref name="Huff7Feb2016"{{cite news | url= http://www.huffingtonpost.in/2016/02/07/zika-virus_0_n_9179776.html | title=How Bharat Biotech Made Its Breakthrough In Developing A Vaccine For Zika Virus | work=The Huffington Post | date=7 February 2016 | agency=Press Trust of India | accessdate=9 February 2016 | author=Bagla, Pallava | location=New Delhi}}</ref> using two approaches: "[[Genetic recombination|recombinant]]", involving genetic engineering, and "inactivated", where the virus is incapable of reproducing itself but can still trigger an immune response with [[Animal testing#Drug testing|animal trials]] of the inactivated version to commence in late February.ref name="Reuters3Feb2016"{{cite news | access-date=8 February 2016 | url= http://www.reuters.com/article/health-zika-vaccine-idUSKCN0VC12U | title=Bharat Biotech says working on two possible Zika vaccines | agency=Reuters | date=3 February 2016 | last=Siddiqi | first=Zeba}}</ref> As ofMarch 2016, 18 companies and institutions internationally were developing vaccines against Zika, but none had yet reached clinical trials.ref name=WHO9Mar2016 The first human trial for Zika vaccine, a synthetic DNA vaccine (GLS-5700) developed by Inovio Pharmaceuticals, is approved by FDA in June 2016. Interim results of the Phase 1 study is expected in later 2016. ref{{cite web|url=http://www.fiercepharma.com/vaccines/inovio-set-for-first-zika-vaccine-human-trial|title=Inovio set for first Zika vaccine human trial|author=Sagonowsky, Eric|publisher=fiercepharma.com|date=21 June 2016|accessdate=1 July 2016}}</ref> Nikos Vasilakis of the [[University of Texas Medical Branch|UTMB]] predicted that it may take two years to develop a vaccine, but ten to twelve years may be needed before an effective Zika vaccine is approved by regulators for public use.ref name="BBC27Jan2016"{{cite news |accessdate=28 January 2016 |url= http://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-35423288 |title=Zika virus: US scientists say vaccine '10 years away' |publisher=BBC News |date=27 January 2016 |last=Cook |first=James}}</ref>A single dose of two distinct vaccine candidates ([[DNA vaccination|DNA]] and [[Inactivated vaccine|inactivated virus vaccine]]) protected mice against the Zika virus.ref{{cite journal | url=http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/vaap/ncurrent/full/nature18952.html | title=Vaccine protection against Zika virus from Brazil | author=Larocca, R. A. | journal=Nature | year=2016 | doi=10.1038/nature18952 | displayauthors=etal}}</ref>== History ==See alsoZika fever#EpidemiologyZika virus outbreak timeline[[File:CDC map of Zika virus distribution name="GathererKohl2016"{{cite journal | url= http://www.microbiologyresearch.org/content/journal/jgv/10.1099/jgv.0.000381.v1 | title=Zika virus: a previously slow pandemic spreads rapidly through the Americas | date=18 December 2015 | last=Gatherer | first=Derek | last2=Kohl | first2=Alain | journal=[[Journal of General Virology]] | volume=97 | issue=2 | pages=269\u2013273 | doi=10.1099/jgv.0.000381 | pmid=26684466}}</ref>ref name="CDCUnitedStates"{{cite web | access-date=20 February 2016 | url= http://www.cdc.gov/zika/geo/united-states.html | title=Zika virus in the United States | publisher=Centers for Disease Control and Prevention}}</ref>]][[File:Molecular-Evolution-of-Zika-Virus-during-Its-Emergence-in-the-20th-Century-pntd.0002636.g002.jpg|thumb|upright=1.5|Spread of Zika in Africa and Asia, based on molecular sequence data]]=== Virus isolation in monkeys and mosquitoes, 1947 ===The virus was first isolated in April 1947 from a [[rhesus macaque]] monkey that had been placed in a cage in the [[Zika Forest]] of [[Uganda]], near [[Lake Victoria]], by the scientists of the [[Uganda Virus Research Institute|Yellow Fever Research Institute]].ref name="Science8Feb2016"{{cite news | url= http://www.sciencemag.org/news/2016/02/zika-s-long-strange-trip-limelight | title=Zika\u2019s long, strange trip into the limelight | work=Science | publisher=American Association for the Advancement of Science | date=8 February 2016 | accessdate=10 February 2016 | author=Cohen, Jon}}</ref> A second isolation from the mosquito ''A. africanus'' followed at the same site in January 1948.ref name="HaddowSchuh2012"{{cite journal | title=Genetic Characterization of Zika Virus Strains: Geographic Expansion of the Asian Lineage | last=Haddow | first=A.D. | last2=Schuh | first2=A.J. | last3=Yasuda | first3=C.Y. | last4=Kasper | first4=M.R. | last5=Heang | first5=V. | last6=Huy | first6=R. | last7=Weaver | first7=S.C. | journal=PLoS Neglected Tropical Diseases | year=2012 | volume=6 | issue=2 | pages=e1477 | doi=10.1371/journal.pntd.0001477 | pmc=3289602 | pmid=22389730 | display-authors=3}}</ref> When the monkey developed a fever, researchers isolated from its [[Serum (blood)|serum]] a [[History of virology|"filterable transmissible agent"]] that was named Zika in 1948.ref name="Hayes2009" ref name="ProMED2Feb2016"{{cite web | url= http://promedmail.org/post/4007411 | title=Zika Virus (06): Overview 2016-02-09 19:58:3 Archive Number: 20160209.4007411 | website=Pro-MED-mail| publisher=International Society for Infectious Diseases }}</ref>=== First evidence of human infection, 1952 ===Zika had been known to infect humans from the results of serological surveys in Uganda and Nigeria, published in 1952: Among 84 people of all ages, 50 individuals had antibodies to Zika, and all above 40 years of age were immune.ref name="DickKitchen1952"{{cite journal | date=September 1952 | first1=G.W.A. | title=Zika Virus (I). Isolations and serological specificity | last2=Kitchen | first2=S.F. | last3=Haddow | first3=A.J. | journal=Transactions of the Royal Society of Tropical Medicine and Hygiene | last1=Dick | url= http://trstmh.oxfordjournals.org/content/46/5/509.short | volume=46 | issue=5 | pages=509\u2013520 | issn=0035-9203 | doi=10.1016/0035-9203(52)90042-4 | pmid=12995440}}</ref> A 1952 research study conducted in India had shown a "significant number" of Indians tested for Zika had exhibited an immune response to the virus, suggesting it had long been widespread within human populations.ref name="BBC2Feb2016"{{cite news | access-date=2 February 2016 | url= http://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-india-35457661 | title=Why Asia should worry about Zika too | publisher=BBC News | date=2 February 2016 | author=Rowlatt, Justin}}</ref>It was not until 1954 that the isolation of Zika from a human was published. This came as part of a 1952 outbreak investigation of jaundice suspected to be yellow fever. It was found in the blood of a 10-year-old Nigerian female with low-grade fever, headache, and evidence of malaria, but no jaundice, who recovered within three days. Blood was injected into the brain of laboratory mice, followed by up to 15 mice passages. The virus from mouse brains was then tested in neutralization tests using rhesus monkey sera specifically immune to Zika. In contrast, no virus was isolated from the blood of two infected adults with fever, jaundice, cough, diffuse joint pains in one and fever, headache, pain behind the eyes and in the joints. Infection was proven by a rise in Zika-specific serum antibodies.ref name=DickKitchen1952 === Spread in equatorial Africa and to Asia, 1951\u20131983 ===From 1951 through 1983, evidence of human infection with Zika was reported from other African countries, such as the Central African Republic, Egypt, Gabon, Sierra Leone, Tanzania, and Uganda, as well as in parts of Asia including India, Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Thailand, Vietnam and Pakistan.ref name="Hayes2009" ref name="Fox22Mar2016"{{cite news | url= http://www.foxnews.com/health/2016/03/22/timeline-zikas-origin-and-global-spread.html | title=Timeline \u2013 Zika's origin and global spread | publisher=Fox News Channel | date=22 March 2016 | accessdate=24 March 2016}}</ref> From its discovery until 2007, there were only 14 confirmed human cases of Zika infection from Africa and Southeast Asia.ref name="NYT10Feb2016"{{cite news | first1=Austin | last1=Ramzy | url= http://www.nytimes.com/2016/02/11/world/asia/zika-virus-yap-island.html | title=Experts Study Zika\u2019s Path From First Outbreak in Pacific | work=[[The New York Times]] | date=10 February 2016 | accessdate=12 February 2016 | location=Hong Kong}}</ref>=== Micronesia, 2007 ===Main article2007 Yap Islands Zika virus outbreakIn April 2007, the first outbreak outside of Africa and Asia occurred on the island of [[Yap]] in the Federated States of Micronesia, characterized by rash, conjunctivitis, and arthralgia, which was initially thought to be dengue, [[chikungunya]], or [[Ross River virus|Ross River disease]].ref name="NYT3Jul2007"{{cite news | url= http://www.nytimes.com/2007/07/03/health/03virus.html| title=Little-Known Virus Challenges a Far-Flung Health System | work=The New York Times | date=3 July 2007 | author=Altman, L.K.}}</ref> Serum samples from patients in the acute phase of illness contained RNA of Zika. There were 49 confirmed cases, 59 unconfirmed cases, no hospitalizations, and no deaths.ref name="DuffyChen2009"{{cite journal | date=11 June 2009 | first1=Mark R. | first10=Christine | first11=Laurent | first12=Anne | first13=Martin | first14=Amy J. | first15=Janeen | first16=Olga | first17=Amanda | first18=Brad J. | first19=Marc | first20=Edward B. | first4=Ann M. | last1=Duffy | last10=Dubray | last11=Guillaumot | last12=Griggs | last13=Bel | last14=Lambert | last15=Laven | last16=Kosoy | last17=Panella | last18=Biggerstaff | last19=Fischer | url= http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMoa0805715 | title=Zika Virus Outbreak on Yap Island, Federated States of Micronesia | last2=Chen | first2=Tai-Ho | first3=W. Thane | last20=Hayes | last3=Hancock | last4=Powers | last5=Kool | first5=Jacob L. | last6=Lanciotti | first6=Robert S. | last7=Pretrick | first7=Moses | last8=Marfel | first8=Maria | last9=Holzbauer | first9=Stacey | journal=New England Journal of Medicine | volume=360 | issue=24 | pages=2536\u20132543 | issn=0028-4793 | doi=10.1056/NEJMoa0805715 | pmid=19516034 | display-authors=3}}</ref>=== 2013\u20132014 ======= Oceania ====expand sectiondate=February 2016Main article2013\u20132014 Zika virus outbreaks in OceaniaBetween 2013 and 2014, further epidemics occurred in [[French Polynesia]], Easter Island, the [[Cook Islands]], and [[New Caledonia]].ref name="eid14" ==== Other cases ====On 22 March 2016 Reuters reported that Zika was isolated from a 2014 blood sample of an elderly man in [[Chittagong]] in [[Bangladesh]] as part of a retrospective study.ref name="Newsweek22Mar2016"{{cite news | url= http://www.newsweek.com/bangladesh-confirms-first-case-zika-virus-439632 | title=Bangladesh Confirms First Case of Zika Virus | work=[[Newsweek]] | date=22 March 2016 | accessdate=22 March 2016}}</ref>=== Americas, 2015\u2013present ===Main article2015\u201316 Zika virus epidemicAs of2016alt=As of early 2016, a widespread outbreak of Zika was ongoing, primarily in the [[Americas]]. The outbreak began in April 2015 in [[Brazil]], and has spread to other countries in [[South America]], [[Central America]], [[Mexico]], and the [[Caribbean]]. In January 2016, the WHO said the virus was likely to spread throughout most of the Americas by the end of the year;ref name="Reuters25Jan2016"{{cite news | url= http://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-zika-idUSKCN0V30U6 | title=WHO sees Zika outbreak spreading through the Americas | agency=[[Reuters]] | date=25 January 2016 | accessdate=25 January 2016}}</ref> and in February 2016, the WHO declared the cluster of microcephaly and Guillain\u2013Barr\u00e9 syndrome cases reported in Brazil \u2013 strongly suspected to be associated with the Zika outbreaksndsa [[Public Health Emergency of International Concern]].ref name="SikkaChattu2016" ref name="WHO1Feb2016"{{cite web | url= http://www.who.int/mediacentre/news/statements/2016/emergency-committee-zika-microcephaly/en/ | title=WHO Director-General summarizes the outcome of the Emergency Committee regarding clusters of microcephaly and Guillain-Barr\u00e9 syndrome | publisher=[[World Health Organization]] | date=1 February 2016 | accessdate=2 February 2016}}</ref>ref name="BBC1Feb2016"{{cite news | access-date=1 Michelle}}</ref>ref name="CNN2Feb2016"{{cite news | access-date=2 February 2016 | url= http://www.cnn.com/2016/02/01/health/zika-virus-public-health-emergency/index.html | title=Zika virus sparks 'public health emergency' | publisher=[[CNN]] | date=2 February 2016 | author=Pearson, Michael}}</ref> It is estimated that 1.5 million people have been infected by Zika in Brazil,ref name="Reuters18Feb2016"{{cite news | first1=Anthony | first2=Tom | last1=Boadle | url= http://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-zika-brazil-idUSKCN0VR2P8 | title=U.S., Brazil researchers join forces to battle Zika virus | agency=[[Reuters]] | date=18 February 2016 | accessdate=4 March 2016 | last2=Brown | last3=Orr | first3=Bernard | location=Brasilia}}</ref> with over 3,500 cases of microcephaly reported between October 2015 and January 2016.ref name="ECDC25Nov2015"{{cite web | url= http://ecdc.europa.eu/en/press/news/_layouts/forms/News_DispForm.aspx?ID=1329&List=8db7286c-fe2d-476c-9133-18ff4cb1b568&Source=http%3A%2F%2Fecdc.europa.eu%2Fen%2FPages%2Fhome.aspx | title=Microcephaly in Brazil potentially linked to the Zika virus epidemic, ECDC assesses the risk | work=News and Media | publisher=[[European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control]] | date=25 November 2015 | accessdate=18 January 2016}}</ref>A number of countries have issued [[travel warning]]s, and the outbreak is expected to significantly impact the tourism industry.ref name="SikkaChattu2016" ref name="WSJ3Feb2016"{{cite news | first1=Paul | last1=Kiernan | url= http://www.wsj.com/articles/zika-fears-imperil-brazils-tourism-push-1454461138 | title=Zika Fears Imperil Brazil\u2019s Tourism Push | work=[[The Wall Street Journal]]| date=3 February 2016 | accessdate=27 February 2016 | last2=Jelmayer | first2=Rogerio}}</ref> Several countries have taken the unusual step of advising their citizens to delay pregnancy until more is known about the virus and its impact on fetal development.ref name=BBC23Jan2016 With the 2016 Olympics Games set to be hosted in Rio de Janeiro, health officials worldwide have voiced concerns over a potential crisis, both in Brazil and when international athletes and tourists, who may be unknowingly infected, return home and possibly spread the virus. Some researchers speculate that only one or two tourists may be infected during the three week period, or approximately 3.2 infections per 100,000 tourists.ref{{cite web |first=Julia |last=Belluz |title=Rio Olympics 2016: why athletes and fans aren't likely to catch Zika. |date= 26 May 2016 |url= http://www.vox.com/2016/5/25/11760228/zika-virus-risk-rio-olympics-2016 |publisher=[[Vox (website)|Vox]] |accessdate=1 June 2016}}</ref>== References ==Research helpMedReflist30emCDC== External links ==* [http://www.cdc.gov/zika/ Zika virus \u2013 Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]* [http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/zika/en/ World Health Organization Zika virus Fact Sheet]* [http://visual-science.com/projects/zika/illustrations/ Zika virus illustrations, 3D model, and animation]* [http://viralzone.expasy.org/all_by_protein/6756.html ViralZone: Zika virus (strain Mr 766)]* [http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/Taxonomy/Browser/wwwtax.cgi?mode=Info&id=64320 Zika virus at NCBI Taxonomy Browser]* cite book editor-first=Samuel editor-last=Baron first=Alan L. last=Schmaljohn first2=David last2=McClain title=Medical Microbiology edition=4th chapterurl= https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK7633/ chapter=54.
